awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CNS Core: Medium: Design and Analysis of Quantum Networks for Entanglement Distribution
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent advances in quantum information processing like quantum key distribution (QKD) are already in deployment ensuring secure end-to-end communication. This is especially important today, because of the risk posed by quantum computing to current Internet-based encryption technology such as RSA. At the same time there is a multitude of emerging quantum information based technologies with a high promise of revolutionizing their respective areas of application. These include ultra-high-precision distributed sensing with applications to metrology and science discovery (e.g., LIGO), much higher-rate deep space optical communications than possible with conventional systems, and polynomial speedups on search with implications to big data. Most of these applications are enabled by high-rate distributed shared quantum entanglement between pairs and groups of users. The goal of this project is to develop a distributed infrastructure in the form of a quantum network to enable reliable, large scale quantum entanglement distribution. Progress in that direction will catalyze quantum computing advances in the same way the Internet boosted computing to conquer most aspects of contemporary economy and society.

The goal of the project is the fully-informed study of the design and operation of quantum networks combining physical-layer device noise models with the ground-up development of higher-layer network protocols. It aspires to bridge the intellectual gap between the quantum information and physics communities who are the ones primarily involved in developing quantum communication protocols, and the networking community who have decades of experience in the design and analysis of practical computer and communication networks. The proposed research will both: (a) inform device needs and specifications pushed down by network application requirements; and (b) help develop network routing and resource allocation protocols optimized for device quality metrics, such as quantum memory coherence times and detector excess noise. The project will culminate in the development of new tools and algorithms for a completely new family of networking protocols for a problem set up and resource constraints that have no immediate classical analogues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary outcome of this project was the development of algorithms for the distribution, management and use of entanglement in a future quantum network. We studied algorithms for switching, routing, distillation, and consumption of entanglement by end-user nodes engaged in a distributed sensing task, which could have applications to use cases such as entanglement based long baseline telescopes. We showed that when heralded entangled Bell pairs are generated across links of a network, among the several actions avaiable at a node at any given point in time---e.g., making joint projective measurements on a collection of qubits entangled with distinct neighboring network nodes, performing entanglement distillation on multiple copies of entanglement with one neighboring node into fewer copies of higher-Fidelity entangled states shared with that same node, or even waiting for some number of time steps to shore up a sufficient number of entangled states with multiple neighbors before performing one of the aforesaid actions---that the optimal action for the node can be dependent on the network topology, and the end-user application-driven quality-of-service metric [Phys. Rev. Applied 22, 064085, 2024]. We also found that depending upon the regime of link quality, entanglement success rates, and probability of success of Bell measurement actions at nodes, that dynamic resource allocation strategies versus routing on pre-determined paths can be better or worse [arXiv:2308.15028], and studied the effect of how the distributed entanglement state's fidelity drops when entanglement spreads in a network via GHZ-state projective measurements [10.1109/QCE57702.2023.00130]. 

As a research by-product, we developed an extensive rulebook for manipulation of many-qubit entangled (stabilizer) states via (Clifford) unitary operations and measurements---including two-qubit Bell-state and GHZ-state projective measurements---purely as rules for manipulating graphs, understanding which does not require the knowledge of stabilizer algebra [arXiv:2312.02377]. Partially funded by this project, we also developed a Tangram (computer) game---playable by a high-school student and higher---where as the player gets better at placing puzzle blocks onto a playing board to match a "circuit" made up of four different colored blocks fly by, they also unknowingly get better at solving the (known hard) problem of resource-efficient mapping of a quantum circuit into the measurement based model of quantum computing [10.1109/QCE53715.2022.00124].
